items.title: Ukraine: How did the meeting between Trump, Zelensky and European leaders go?
items.standfirst: Russian and Ukrainian presidents Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelensky looked set for a peace summit after fast-moving talks Monday between Donald Trump and European leaders that focused on the key issue of long-term security guarantees for Kyiv. Analysis by FRANCE 24 international Affairs Editor, Philip Turle.

items.title: War in Ukraine: Trump says arranging Putin-Zelensky summit
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said Monday he had started arranging a peace summit between Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelensky and Russia's Vladimir Putin, after intensive talks with Zelensky and European leaders at the White House. Trump said he had spoken by phone with Putin -- whom he met in Alaska last week -- following a "very good" meeting with the Europeans and the Ukrainian president in the White House. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Ukraine, Emmanuelle Chaze.
items.content: US President Donald Trump said Monday he had started arranging a peace summit between Ukraine's Volodymyr Zelensky and Russia's Vladimir Putin, after intensive talks with Zelensky and European leaders at the White House. Trump said he had spoken by phone with Putin -- whom he met in Alaska last week -- following a "very good" meeting with the Europeans and the Ukrainian president in the White House. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Ukraine, Emmanuelle Chaze.

items.title: Zelensky says ready for bilateral meeting with Putin to end war
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Monday he was willing to meet directly with his Russian counterpart to end the war. Speaking to reporters after talks with US President Donald Trump and several European leaders at the White House, Zelensky said he was ready for what would be his first face-to-face with Vladimir Putin since Moscow's invasion nearly three and a half years ago. Story by Bryan Quinn.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Monday he was willing to meet directly with his Russian counterpart to end the war. Speaking to reporters after talks with US President Donald Trump and several European leaders at the White House, Zelensky said he was ready for what would be his first face-to-face with Vladimir Putin since Moscow's invasion nearly three and a half years ago. Story by Bryan Quinn.

items.title: War in Ukraine live: Putin is 'an ogre at our gates', France's Macron says
items.standfirst: Russian President Vladimir Putin is “a predator” and “an ogre at our gates”, President Emmanuel Macron said in an interview with French station LCI Tuesday, warning that Putin “needs to keep eating” for “his own survival”. The French president also suggested that a future meeting between Putin and his Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky could take place in Geneva, Switzerland. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.
items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin is “a predator” and “an ogre at our gates”, President Emmanuel Macron said in an interview with French station LCI Tuesday, warning that Putin “needs to keep eating” for “his own survival”. The French president also suggested that a future meeting between Putin and his Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky could take place in Geneva, Switzerland. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.

items.title: Donning 'fabulous' outfit, Zelensky melds fashion and diplomacy
items.standfirst: Six months removed from the shocking dressing down he received at the hands of US President Donald Trump and Vice President JD Vance, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky traded his trademark military-style garb for a sharp black suit for his high-stakes return to the White House on Monday, indulging Trump's perception of clothing choice as a mark of gratitude.
items.content: Six months removed from the shocking dressing down he received at the hands of US President Donald Trump and Vice President JD Vance, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky traded his trademark military-style garb for a sharp black suit for his high-stakes return to the White House on Monday, indulging Trump's perception of clothing choice as a mark of gratitude.

items.title: France's Emmanuel Macron says he doesn't believe Putin is 'very willing to get peace' in Ukraine

items.content: There must be a push for peace to end the war between Russia and Ukraine, but French President Emmanuel Macron is skeptical that Russian President Vladimir Putin is ready to resolve the conflict.

items.title: Zelensky, European allies push for Ukraine ceasefire, security guarantees in high stakes DC summit
items.standfirst: Following a fruitless meeting between US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin last week, Trump hosted Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and his European allies at the White House on Monday, just hours after Russia launched a crushing attack in Ukraine. After Trump seemingly aligned with Putin, dropping threats of sanctions and his support for a ceasefire, Zelensky and his allies pushed back, emphasising the need for a pause in fighting and security guarantees for Ukraine in any potential peace deal.
items.content: Following a fruitless meeting between US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin last week, Trump hosted Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and his European allies at the White House on Monday, just hours after Russia launched a crushing attack in Ukraine. After Trump seemingly aligned with Putin, dropping threats of sanctions and his support for a ceasefire, Zelensky and his allies pushed back, emphasising the need for a pause in fighting and security guarantees for Ukraine in any potential peace deal.

items.title: Trump's endorsement of Kremlin lies 'problematic', researcher says
items.standfirst: FRANCE 24's Mark Owen speaks to Jaroslava Barbieri, Research Fellow at the Ukraine Forum of Chatham House, about the latest meeting between US President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. She says that Trump's endorsement of 'lies that the Kremlin has been consistently pushing' is problematic and that the 'dimension of justice as a key component for a durable peace in Ukraine is completely absent' from the talks.
items.content: FRANCE 24's Mark Owen speaks to Jaroslava Barbieri, Research Fellow at the Ukraine Forum of Chatham House, about the latest meeting between US President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. She says that Trump's endorsement of 'lies that the Kremlin has been consistently pushing' is problematic and that the 'dimension of justice as a key component for a durable peace in Ukraine is completely absent' from the talks.

items.title: Live: Zelensky arrives at White House for Ukraine ceasefire talks with Trump, European leaders
Zelensky urges Trump to bring 'peace through strength' against Russia
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Monday urged Donald Trump to exert "peace through strength" against Russia, echoing the US leader's own language ahead of a high-stakes White House meeting. "Russia can only be forced into peace through strength, and President Trump has that strength. We have to do everything right to make peace happen," Zelensky wrote on X. Analysis by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Emmanuelle Chaze.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Monday urged Donald Trump to exert "peace through strength" against Russia, echoing the US leader's own language ahead of a high-stakes White House meeting. "Russia can only be forced into peace through strength, and President Trump has that strength. We have to do everything right to make peace happen," Zelensky wrote on X. Analysis by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Emmanuelle Chaze.

items.title: Trump to plan sit-down meeting with Zelenskyy and Putin

items.content: Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy meets with President Donald Trump at the White House, just days after Trump and Russia’s President Vladimir Putin left an Alaska summit without a ceasefire deal.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Trump discussed Ukraine's security with European leaders, aiming for a Zelenskyy-Putin summit.
• European leaders met virtually after White House talks, focusing on security guarantees.
• Trump believes he is skilled at conflict resolution, potentially boosting US arms industry.
• The meeting between Zelenskyy and Trump in February ended abruptly due to disagreements.
• Oil prices declined by over 1% as investors considered Ukraine peace efforts.

• SoftBank agreed to invest $2 billion in Intel, acquiring a 2% stake in the company.
• The Trump administration is reportedly considering a 10% stake in Intel.
• The government could become Intel's largest shareholder if the deal proceeds.
• Intel shares increased after SoftBank announced its investment in the chipmaker.
• The investment from SoftBank is part of a larger trend of US investment.

The carrier said it will gradually resume its operations

clusters.ai_summary:
• Air Canada flight attendants reached a tentative agreement with the airline.
• The strike, which had lasted for four days, has ended.
• The Canadian Union of Public Employees announced the end of the strike.
• Both parties confirmed the tentative agreement to end the strike.
• Air Canada will gradually resume its operations following the agreement.

clusters.title: Hamas accepts proposed deal for ceasefire with Israel and hostage release

bullet_summary: There was no Israeli response to the Hamas proposal itself but an Israeli official confirmed it was received
The $2tn wealth fund did not name the companies it had decided to exclude, but said these would be made public once the divestment was completed, Reuters reports

items.title: Hamas accepts proposed deal for ceasefire with Israel and hostage release
items.standfirst: Hamas has agreed to a 60-day ceasefire proposal with Israel that includes the return of half the hostages held in Gaza and Israel's release of some Palestinian prisoners. There was no Israeli response to the Hamas proposal itself but an Israeli official confirmed it was received. Egypt and Qatar have been mediating between the sides with U.S. support. Story by Kalidou Sy and August Hakansson.
items.content: Hamas has agreed to a 60-day ceasefire proposal with Israel that includes the return of half the hostages held in Gaza and Israel's release of some Palestinian prisoners. There was no Israeli response to the Hamas proposal itself but an Israeli official confirmed it was received. Egypt and Qatar have been mediating between the sides with U.S. support. Story by Kalidou Sy and August Hakansson.

items.title: Hamas source says group agrees to latest Gaza ceasefire proposal
items.standfirst: The proposal from regional mediators would see Israeli hostages released in two batches during a 60-day truce, according to a Palestinian official.
items.content: The proposal from regional mediators would see Israeli hostages released in two batches during a 60-day truce, according to a Palestinian official.

items.title: Hamas says it accepts proposal for Gaza ceasefire and release of hostages
items.standfirst: Deal would include 60-day halt to violence and exchange of half of living Israeli hostages for Palestinian prisonersHamas officials say they have accepted a proposal for a Gaza ceasefire deal that would include the release of half of the approximately 20 remaining living Israeli hostages as part of a phased resolution to the war, as Gaza health officials said 62,000 Palestinians had died in the 22 months of war.The proposed deal follows negotiations between Hamas and Egyptian and Qatari officials that have been taking place in Cairo in recent days, and comes after the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, was confronted on Sunday by Israel’s biggest protests of the war, which called for a deal to secure the release of the hostages. Continue reading...
items.content: Deal would include 60-day halt to violence and exchange of half of living Israeli hostages for Palestinian prisonersHamas officials say they have accepted a proposal for a Gaza ceasefire deal that would include the release of half of the approximately 20 remaining living Israeli hostages as part of a phased resolution to the war, as Gaza health officials said 62,000 Palestinians had died in the 22 months of war.The proposed deal follows negotiations between Hamas and Egyptian and Qatari officials that have been taking place in Cairo in recent days, and comes after the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, was confronted on Sunday by Israel’s biggest protests of the war, which called for a deal to secure the release of the hostages. Continue reading...

items.title: Hamas 'agrees to ceasefire deal', say officials
items.standfirst: Hamas has agreed to a ceasefire deal, in which half the hostages being held in Gaza will be freed in return for Israel releasing some Palestinian prisoners, according to senior diplomats.
items.content: Hamas has agreed to a ceasefire deal, in which half the hostages being held in Gaza will be freed in return for Israel releasing some Palestinian prisoners, according to senior diplomats.

items.title: Netanyahu criticises protests in Israel against his handling of Gaza war
items.standfirst: Israeli PM suggests demonstrators are toughening Hamas’s stance and delaying the release of hostagesBenjamin Netanyahu has criticised massive street protests against his handling of the Gaza war, and failure to secure the release of remaining Israeli hostages, suggesting demonstrators were giving comfort to Hamas’s position in negotiations.The Israeli prime minister made his comments against the backdrop of the largest protests in almost two years of war, with estimates that upwards of 400,000 people joined marches across Israel on Sunday. Continue reading...
items.content: Israeli PM suggests demonstrators are toughening Hamas’s stance and delaying the release of hostagesBenjamin Netanyahu has criticised massive street protests against his handling of the Gaza war, and failure to secure the release of remaining Israeli hostages, suggesting demonstrators were giving comfort to Hamas’s position in negotiations.The Israeli prime minister made his comments against the backdrop of the largest protests in almost two years of war, with estimates that upwards of 400,000 people joined marches across Israel on Sunday. Continue reading...

clusters.ai_summary:
• Hamas agreed to a 60-day ceasefire proposal with Israel.
• The proposal includes the release of half of the hostages held in Gaza.
• Israel would release some Palestinian prisoners as part of the deal.
• The deal follows negotiations between Hamas and Egyptian and Qatari officials.
• The proposed deal would halt violence and exchange hostages for prisoners.

clusters.title: The ‘big church move’: Swedish town begins to roll historic building 5km
clusters.neutral_headline: Swedish Church Relocated to Make Way for Mine Expansion
bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, Reuters Top News, France24

items.title: The ‘big church move’: Swedish town begins to roll historic building 5km
items.standfirst: Kiruna Kyrka’s slow journey is part of effort to stop town being swallowed by Europe’s biggest underground mineAfter eight years of planning, an estimated cost of 500m kronor (£39m) and an early morning blessing, a church in northern Sweden began a slow-motion 5km journey on Tuesday to make way for the expansion of Europe’s biggest underground mine.The 672-tonne Kiruna Kyrka, a Swedish Lutheran church inaugurated in 1912, is to be slowly rolled to its new home over two days, at a pace of half-a-kilometre an hour. Continue reading...
items.content: Kiruna Kyrka’s slow journey is part of effort to stop town being swallowed by Europe’s biggest underground mineAfter eight years of planning, an estimated cost of 500m kronor (£39m) and an early morning blessing, a church in northern Sweden began a slow-motion 5km journey on Tuesday to make way for the expansion of Europe’s biggest underground mine.The 672-tonne Kiruna Kyrka, a Swedish Lutheran church inaugurated in 1912, is to be slowly rolled to its new home over two days, at a pace of half-a-kilometre an hour. Continue reading...

items.title: Historic Swedish church on the move in logistical feat
items.standfirst: The church is one of 23 cultural buildings relocated to the new Kiruna town centre to make way for the expansion of Europe's biggest underground mine
items.content: The church is one of 23 cultural buildings relocated to the new Kiruna town centre to make way for the expansion of Europe's biggest underground mine

items.title: 'The Great Church Walk': Historic Swedish church moves to allow mine expansion
items.standfirst: A Swedish Lutheran church dating from 1912 sets off Tuesday on remote-controlled flatbed trailers to find a new home five kilometres away from its original location in the Arctic town of Kiruna. The logistical feat of the church's displacement – to make way for the expansion of Europe's largest underground mine – has attracted widespread interest and sparked a live TV show.
items.content: A Swedish Lutheran church dating from 1912 sets off Tuesday on remote-controlled flatbed trailers to find a new home five kilometres away from its original location in the Arctic town of Kiruna. The logistical feat of the church's displacement – to make way for the expansion of Europe's largest underground mine – has attracted widespread interest and sparked a live TV show.

clusters.ai_summary:
• A historic Swedish church began a 5km journey to make way for a mine.
• The church is being moved to allow for the expansion of a mine.
• The church weighs 672 tonnes and is being moved slowly.
• The relocation is part of a project to move cultural buildings.
• The church's move has attracted widespread interest and a live TV show.

clusters.title: Texas Democrat locked in state Capitol after refusing police escort
clusters.neutral_headline: Texas Democrats Return Home, Ending Redistricting Standoff
bullet_summary: Reported by CBS News, Politico

items.title: Texas Democrat locked in state Capitol after refusing police escort
items.standfirst: House leaders mandated police escorts for Democrats to guarantee they return for Wednesday's session.
items.content: House leaders mandated police escorts for Democrats to guarantee they return for Wednesday's session.

items.title: Texas Democrats have returned home, ending redistricting standoff
items.standfirst: The Democrats will each be escorted by law enforcement officers to ensure they return Wednesday, as the state GOP prepares to pass a new congressional map.
items.content: Texas Democrats who left the state to stymie Republicans over redistricting have returned to Austin, ending a two-week standoff over President Donald Trump's plan to carve out five new GOP congressional seats. Their return to the state means the Texas House now has the sufficient number of legislators needed to pass a new map benefiting the GOP. Democrats had used the gambit to stall legislative business and bring national attention to Republicans’ decision to pursue off-cycle redistricting ahead of the midterms. In a statement, the Texas House Democratic Caucus said that members returned on Monday morning “to launch the next phase in their fight against the racist gerrymander that provoked a weeks-long standoff with Governor [Greg] Abbott and President Trump.” The drama in Texas set off a national redistricting battle, most prominently with California Gov. Gavin Newsom vowing to retaliate against Texas Republicans by extracting an equal number of Democratic-leaning districts from California’s congressional map. Trump has also been pushing to take his redistricting plan to other Republican-led states, like Indiana and Missouri. After Democrats returned to the state capitol, the House gaveled into session Monday afternoon with enough members to make quorum and conduct official business for the first time in weeks. The map and other legislation now heads to committees before the session resumes Wednesday. That prompted one more public show of force from the GOP: House Speaker Dustin Burrows on Monday assigned state law enforcement officers to escort the returned Democrats over the next two days, ensuring they come back to Austin on Wednesday. Texas Republican leaders had previously authorized Department of Public Safety officers to canvass the state and stationed them outside lawmakers' homes while they were outside the state. Texas Democrats debated how long to stay away from the state, but ultimately laid out two conditions for their return: that the legislature end its first special session and that California lawmakers introduce their own map granting Democrats five more seats to counter Texas. Both of those occurred on Friday, prompting the Texas lawmakers to start returning home. By breaking quorum, the members racked up hundreds of thousands of dollars in fines. It also set off a legal fight brought by Abbott and Attorney General Ken Paxton, who sought to remove some of the Democrats from office. Aid for Central Texas flood victims was held up by the standoff. Republicans put redistricting first on the legislative calendar, ahead of disaster relief considerations — a move that Democrats called out as irresponsible. The GOP, in response, argued that Democrats were delaying that relief by remaining out of state. Abbott had promised to continue calling special sessions after the first one ended, beginning with a second one that began on Friday — a move that added to the pressure he and other GOP leaders exerted on Democrats to end their protest.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Texas Democrats returned home, ending the redistricting standoff.
• House leaders mandated police escorts for Democrats.
• The state GOP is preparing to pass a new congressional map.
• Democrats will be escorted by law enforcement.
• The Democrats ended their protest by returning home.

clusters.title: Carlos Alcaraz wins Cincinnati Open final after Jannik Sinner retires

bullet_summary: The Italian said he had been feeling unwell since Sunday and could no longer continue
Reported by Al Jazeera, France24

items.title: Carlos Alcaraz wins Cincinnati Open final after Jannik Sinner retires
items.standfirst: The defending champ pulls out with illness, raising questions about his preparations before next Sunday's US Open.
items.content: The defending champ pulls out with illness, raising questions about his preparations before next Sunday's US Open.

items.title: Carlos Alcaraz wins Cincinnati Open after Jannik Sinner retires
items.standfirst: The dream final never materialised. Jannik Sinner was forced to retire in the first set due to illness against Carlos Alcaraz in the Cincinnati Open final. The Italian said he had been feeling unwell since Sunday and could no longer continue. For Alcaraz, it’s his sixth title of the year and his first in Cincinnati.
items.content: The dream final never materialised. Jannik Sinner was forced to retire in the first set due to illness against Carlos Alcaraz in the Cincinnati Open final. The Italian said he had been feeling unwell since Sunday and could no longer continue. For Alcaraz, it’s his sixth title of the year and his first in Cincinnati.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Carlos Alcaraz won the Cincinnati Open final.
• Jannik Sinner retired from the match due to illness.
• Sinner had been feeling unwell since Sunday.
• Alcaraz's victory marks his sixth title of the year.
• This is Alcaraz's first Cincinnati Open title.
